awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Toward Scalable Manufacturing of Nanostructured Organic Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Early Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award provides funding for the development of a scalable nanomanufacturing technology for achieving high performance organic light-emitting diodes. Imprinting molds will be fabricated on which two levels of nanoscale geometry will be vertically stacked. The first level of the mold will define nanostructured organic emission layer that improves light extraction from the organic light-emitting diode, while the second level will define nanostructured anode-organic interface that improves positive charge injection into the light-emitting layer. Experiments involving varying the design of the nanoscale imprinting geometry will be performed, and both small molecule and polymer based nanostructured organic light-emitting diodes will be fabricated and characterized. The developed technology will be implemented to a roll-to-roll manufacturing system through an established industrial collaboration.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to a scalable approach that can overcome the challenge of mold misalignment and dimensional change encountered in traditional large area roll-to-roll nanomanufacturing processes due to the use of a sequence of masks. The primary goal of this work is to develop and apply the multi-level single-mold nanoimprinting technology that will enable the realization of high performance organic light-emitting diodes having nanostructures that can enhance light extraction and charge injection. In addition to a scalable nanomanufacturing tool, the proposed work will also contribute to the field of energy efficiency by developing high performance light-emitting diodes as a next generation lighting source.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
The structure of a standard OLED typically consists of, in sequence, an anode, a stack of organic medium, and a cathode. One of the basic requirements for efficient operation of OLEDs is the process of carrier injection and subsequent transport from the electrodes into the organic light-emitting layer. As the energy barrier for carrier injection is determined by the energy difference between the work function of the electrode and the ionization potential/electron affinity of the organic material, efficient injection of electrons and holes into organics may be achieved in principle by matching the cathode and anode work functions with the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) or the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of the organic molecules, respectively. Nevertheless, a simple stable metallic cathode does not have sufficiently low work function for efficient electron injection, and the work function of a standard transparent ITO anode is not high enough for effective hole injection. On the other hand, a typical OLED device comprises a multilayer structure built on a flat transparent substrate. Each layer is between 10 to 100 nm thick, with refractive indices that differ significantly. A simple estimate of the planar OLED structure using classical optics indicates that OLED devices contain planar organic layers deposited on an ITO covered glass substrate (with typical organics refractive index of 1.7) have about 20% efficiency for light out-coupling. A large fraction of the light produced in the organic emission layer is trapped, which reduces the overall light extraction, thus constitutes a major obstacle for using OLEDs for large-area displays and lighting sources.

 

Through theoretical and experimental studies, we identified an optimization approach for scalable manufacturing of high performance OLED devices, via nano- and micro- scale structural modifications of OLEDs at two distinctive length scales, that enables enhanced carrier injection and light extraction. Theoretically, we studied the influence of nanostructures on electrical enhancement effects in a doubly injection-limited OLED. We performed a numerical analysis using a carrier-decoupled, injection-limited model, through reduction of the multi-dimensional semiconductor equations, and applied it to periodic nanoimprint column geometries with varying dimensions to estimate the consequent electrical enhancement and optimized geometries for the designed nanoscale interface modifications. We found that the total current enhancement factor of 2.2 and 3.9 can be achieved for the optimized OLED interface geometries with respective 10 nm and 20 nm imprint thicknesses into a 100 nm-thick organic layer. The asymmetrical nature of the current enhancement was also found to promote current balance in the OLED devices by augmenting cathode-side injection current. Experimentally, we fabricated OLED devices by patterning the cathode-organic interface, which generates an interfacial nanostructure with characteristic feature size on the order of 10 nm. Device performance showed significantly improved performance as compared to unstructured devices, consistent with theoretical analysis. Furthermore, we developed a hybrid composite nanostructure to take advantages from both organic polymers and quantum dots through effective quantum mechanical energy transfer. OLED devices based on such a nanocomposite showed a good promise in providing color purity and stability as well as device robustness.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2016
Modified by: Samuel S Mao
